newsitem.title: JAPAN: JGBs surge toward close, rise to new high.
newsitem.headline: JGBs surge toward close, rise to new high.

text.p: Key December Japanese government bond futures ended sharply higher and set a new high in late afternoon trade on Tuesday.
Traders said the December's advance was led by purchases related to hedge demand by banks which paid fixed interest rates in the swap market.
"Purchases to fulfil hedging needs were first seen yesterday," said a brokerage trader.
"The swap market lacks liquidity, so once things start moving there seems to be a tendency to shift to Euroyen futures and JGB futures to satisfy hedging needs," he said.
The December reached a new high of 123.96, and ended at 123.90, up sharply from Monday's 123.58. Turnover was 41,128 contracts.
Regarding the December's surge in the afternoon, a city bank trader said: "Those who bought stock index futures and sold bond futures before the elections are unwinding their positions now."

Expectations of a money flow from investment funds, set up under a government scheme to clear up the bad loan mess at failed mortgage firms, into the JGB market may also be supporting the market, the city bank trader said.
There was talk that agricultural financial institutions and the New Financial Stabilisation Fund may buy the soon-to-be issued 10-year JGBs, the brokerage trader said.
The Ministry of Finance said on Tuesday, its auction of 2.9 percent 10-year JGBs produced a lowest price of 100.35 yen. MOF said the average price was 100.40.
"There seems to have been some demand from regional investors and some city banks," the brokerage trader said.
Since there was some concern earlier about how the auction would turn out, the results may have reassured the market, and contributed to the bullish sentiment, he added.
Traders said they are watching to see whether government-guaranteed and municipal bonds will be offered at a coupon rate of 2.9 percent or three percent.
"The terms are to be set tomorrow, and it's hard to tell at this point which coupon rate will be adopted," a trader for a city bank's securities affiliate said.

Finance Minister Wataru Kubo said on Tuesday the three parties in the outgoing coalition have not made a decision on forming an extra stimulative budget for this year. Traders said few market participants believe a large supplementary budget is a viable option. -- Masayuki Kitano, Tokyo Treasury Desk
